text:
- We're in the first
minute in Milwaukee,

Isiah spinning, [inaudible]
and hitting it for the Pistons.

- [inaudible] to
Isiah, Isiah racing,
fights for position left wing.

Faked and turned
back to the baseline.

Pushed off the
glass and hits it.
- He got it.
- Number 11, Isiah Thomas.

ISIAH THOMAS: It's been a
very interesting season,

the scoring, the shot making,
the record breaking that's

happening and occurring on
the offensive side of the ball
is historical.

From a defensive standpoint,
you're like, whoa,

can we get a little
defense back?

But I think the
players are phenomenal.
You love watching it.

It's entertaining, and
it's been great to watch.

- In the half left, Isiah
quickly up the right side.
Straight for [inaudible].

ISIAH THOMAS: Well, you can
have hug, and friendship,
and kill at the same time.
[laughing]

I think with
rivalries, they aren't
as bitter as they used to be.

And I do think that
that's something

that all sports require,
that genuine dislike,
competitiveness.

It really does bring
out the best in you.

At some point in time, I do
think you have some bitterness.

If Golden State gets
back to the finals,

and Cleveland gets
back to the finals,

there's some
bitterness there that
can turn into some real hate.
[music playing]

I don't know if it's
evolved or reverted

back to the game of the '50s
and the game of the early '60s.
The jump shot was a thing.
Ball handling was a thing.

The ABA and everybody
else came in.
Dr. J came in with the big hair.

And he was dunking and
doing stuff above the rim.

You had the Harlem
Globetrotters,

Connie Hawkins, and some
of their wizardry then.

You had the above-the-rim
game, and we
had the below-the-rim game.

Right now we just have
the below-the-rim game.

So when you say evolve, I
don't know if it's evolved
or it's going back to.
But whatever it is, we like it.
[cheering]
